utterances: MARKETPLACE's Sam Eaton is here now.
And Sam, most predictions are for a quarter point interest rate cut today from the Fed, but could this new report alter that decision from the Fed?
Well, there's really no way to know for sure until the Fed makes its announcement later today.
But so far there are - there are few clues as to what it's going to do other than the usual rush of predictions coming from economists.
As you mentioned, most of those economists are forecasting at least a quarter point cut in interest rates.
Mark Zandi with MoodysEconomy.com falls into that category.
He says there is a reason today strong economic growth figures won't affect the Fed's decision, and that's because things are changing so fast in the economy.

I would look at history to try to gauge which way the Fed's going to move today, because when they're setting policy today, they're thinking about the future, what the economy is going to look down the road, not what the economy did up till now.
Now, Zandi says even though the GDP acts as a scoreboard for U.S.
economic health, there is a lag effect, and that's the history comment.
Once you look into the future, he says, the picture doesn't look so good.
Much of that growth was fueled by a bump in consumer spending.
And if yesterday's news that consumer confidence slipped again for the third straight month is any indication, that bump in spending isn't likely to last.
Okay.
So if they do cut it by a quarter point, the interest rate, will that be enough to get the economy back on track?
Well, at the very least, Madeleine, it's going to please Wall Street and the markets will respond positively or at least remain somewhat steady.
But I wouldn't expect a rate cut to end the housing woes anytime soon.
The thinking is that a rate cut will improve banks' balance sheets, since they can charge more for their long-term loans while fattening their profits on the cheaper short term loans.
But the credit crunch that's responsible for the housing downturn has much deeper roots.
The big homebuilders are struggling with tightened lending standards and virtually no demand for new housing.
And most buyers can't get loans.
A Fed rate cut isn't going to change that, and some economists say it's a matter of time before that reality catches up to consumers and begins to drag down the overall economy.
And housing's not only problem here, is it?
No, it's definitely not.
Cutting interest rates is always somewhat of gamble.
The key concern is whether it will push up inflation.
The dollar has sunk to new record lows, making foreign goods more expensive.
But the true wildcard here is oil.
The lower the dollar falls, the higher the price of oil goes.
Those costs will be passed on to the larger economy, affecting everything from energy prices to the cost of manufactured goods.
How this plays out is anyone's guess, and I think as far as the Feds goes, it's holding it's breath on this one and hoping for the best.
Thank you, Sam.
That's Sam Eaton of public radio's daily business show MARKETPLACE, produced by American Public Media.
It is no longer Election Day, but it sure feels like it in a few parts of the country.
In Georgia, in Florida, in Arizona, there are big races still too close to call.
Need I tell you, lawsuits have been filed.
And the president of the United States, before heading overseas, he weighed in today on one of those contentious races - the Florida Senate.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
All of a sudden, they're finding votes out of nowhere.
And Rick Scott, who won by - you know, it was close, but he won by a comfortable margin.
Every couple of hours, it goes down a little bit.
Rick Scott, a reference there to the governor of Florida, who would like to become a senator from Florida.
NPR's lead political editor Domenico Montanaro is here.
Hey there.
Hey there.
What is going on in Florida?
Well, first of all, a little bit of a fact check on the president.
I mean, you know, these are provisional ballots and not at all outside the normal range of what happens in close elections.
This happens every single time, and it's happened once...
It takes a while to count all the votes and have them all come in.
Yeah.
There's a big difference between what's projected on election night and the vote that winds up having to be counted before it can be certified, so just to put that out there.
Right now in Florida, we're seeing the two marquee statewide races for governor and Senate are likely headed to state-mandated recounts.
That's because they're both within the 0.5 percentage-point margin to trigger that.
We'll probably find something out about that tomorrow to figure out where that's going to go.

And we're - if a machine recount - this is what would be ordered - happens, and the race, especially for the Senate, which right now is within this margin, is within 0.25 percentage points - really narrow - then a manual recount would be triggered, which is - this is a huge state.
That's a lot of manual work to do.
And the earliest we'd see results from that would be next Saturday.
And it's of course gotten...
Next Saturday, a week from tomorrow?
A week from tomorrow.
OK.
Right.
And, you know, it's already gotten ugly.
We heard Rick Scott talk about, you know, how liberals - he thinks - are trying to steal the election, pointing to election officials in south Florida.
And the president we heard there weighing in.
OK.
Now, that's the Senate race.
What about on the governor's race in Florida, which Andrew Gillum, the Democratic candidate, conceded on Tuesday night?
He did.
But, you know, concessions are really political terms of art, (laughter) you know?
We saw Al Gore, for example, in the 2000 presidential race concede to President Bush.
But if the Senate - if the Supreme Court...
Of - well, if the Supreme Court had gone any differently, he would have happily gone on to be president, so let's just put that out there.
And, you know, as these provisional ballots and other votes have been counted, the race between Gillum and the Republican, Ron DeSantis, who is ahead, has gotten tighter.
Pause with me for a moment just to (laughter) note we are talking Florida - you mentioned Al Gore - we're talking Florida, the home of the hanging chad, where all this is unfolding.
(Laughter) Absolutely.
Lots of close races over the years.
Yeah.
Walk over the state line to Georgia with me and talk about the governor's race, where Republican Brian Kemp has declared himself a winner.
But it's not over there yet either?
That's right.
That race is still considered too close to call.
Kemp is barely above the 50 percent threshold to avoid a runoff.
Lawsuits have been filed there by Democrats about how the election was administered.
Remember, there were a lot of voters waiting in very long lines for hours and hours on Election Day.
And we're still days away from any finality of where that race is going.
But Kemp is ahead.
And the latest in Arizona, where the Senate race there is still too close to call?
Another tight race and another one where the president tweeted questioning the election results, saying that there were the signatures that were counted twice.
Yes, signatures get looked at.
If they don't match, they don't get counted.
So he should talk to the Republican secretary of state (laughter) in that state for how that's administered.
And any timing on when we might know what's going on in Arizona?
Well, right now the Republican, Martha McSally, is leading - was leading on election night.
Now Kyrsten Sinema has edged out a small lead.
There are still some 300,000 ballots left to be counted for early votes that were delivered on Election Day.
So that could take a week or so.
And the race could still go either way.
NPR's Domenico Montanaro, thanks as ever.
You're welcome.
A new film company aimed at black audiences is in the works, but its giving our commentator Lester Spence a sense of déjà vu.
That's because one of the media moguls behind the new studio is Bob Johnson, founder of BET, and Spence says he has a history of letting black audiences down.
The New York Times reports that Bob Johnson will be collaborating with Harvey Weinstein to form a film company that will initially produce low-cost films for the urban market.
According to Johnson, never before has an African-American had this combination of green light authority and significant financial backing.
The film company plans at the outset to specialize in black family comedies.
On the one hand, this marks a watershed event in black media history.
Blacks in the film industry have tried to leverage their power to produce and direct films that tell our stories.

Not only have insiders like Richard Pryor and Harry Belafonte and independents like Haile Garima tried, but organizations like Delta Sigma Theta have also fought for the space to tell our stories on the big screen as well.

And with the recent success of Tyler Perry's Madea series, it is clear that there is a niche for black family movies that don't involve grime, drugs, and gangsters barely old enough to drive, much less vote.
But I'm thinking we've seen this before.
New studio starts from scratch, wanting to carve a name out for itself, promising original programming.
New studio produces inexpensive programs that focus on blacks, because blacks represent an underserved market.
As soon as new studio builds enough market share, they ditch the underserved market.
FOX, UPN, and the WB all used this strategy to various degrees of success.
Bob Johnson's venture is obviously different given his founding of BET, but let's look closely at what BET promised versus what it actually delivered.
When Bob Johnson started BET, he pitched it as a television station that would give black people the opportunity to get quality black sports, news, and entertainment programming.
To African-Americans living in cable markets that did not or would not offer BET, he urged them to protest, to demand a television network that would treat black people with respect and dignity.
We all know how that turned out, don't we?

Bob Johnson took that original vision and gutted it with a quickness about as soon as he recognized that he could make literally billions offering bootie shaking music videos that cost him little to nothing to put on the air.
And when asked about his original vision, all of a sudden he wasn't in the game to produce quality programming for black people.
He was in the game to make money.
I'm a businessman, first and foremost.
To quote that old-time Negro spiritual, it's all about the Benjamins.
What?
Judging by his history, I expect that at the beginning we'll see a number of bland, black comedies, similar in form and content to the Tyler Perry Madea series.
Though the next film that I see starring a cross-dressing black male actor will be my second, these films are far better than the largely forgettable black comedies of the ‘90s.
Even trying to remember films like Bootie Call and B.A.P.S.
makes my head hurt.

But for those expecting this watershed moment to produce watershed black films - of dramas that emphasize black power, dignity, and worth in the face of discrimination - I'd suggest you look elsewhere.
